text: I was born and raised in Dakar Senegal
and through a combination of accident
and cosmic justice became a chef in the
US when I first arrived in New York I
began working with restaurants different
types of restaurants from French bistro
to Italian global ethnic to modern
American at the time New York was
already West well established as a food
capital of the world however in the
exception of a few West African and
Ethiopian mom-and-pop eateries there was
no such thing as African cuisine in the
entire city early in my life I was
influenced by Senegal's first president
léopold sédar Senghor nicknamed the poet
president who talked about a new
humanism a universal civilization in
which all cultures will come together
around a communal table as equals each
bringing its own beautiful contribution
to share he called it the rendezvous of
giving and receiving that concept
resonated with me and it has guided my
career path after years of working in
restaurants I heard for my work to have
a deeper impact that will go beyond the
last meal I had served I wanted to give
back both to New York the city that
allowed me the opportunity to follow my
calling but also to my origins and
ancestors in Senegal I wanted to
contribute to that Universal
civilization Sango had described but I
didn't know how to make a measurable
impact as a cook and writer while I was
writing my first cookbook I often
traveled to different regions of Senegal
for research during one of those trips
in the remote southeast region of kodoku
and we discovered an ancient grain
called for no that had all but
disappeared from the urban senegalese
diet it turns out that fonio had been
cultivated for more than 5,000 years and
is probably the oldest cultivated cereal
in africa once a popular grain in much
of the continent fauna was grown all the
way to ancient Egypt where
archaeologists found grains inside
pyramids burial grounds today it is
mostly coastal cultivated in the western
part of the Sahel region from Senegal to
Mali Burkina Faso Togo Nigeria the Sahel
region is that part semi-arid area south
of the Sahara Desert that if tens from
the Atlantic in the west to the Red Sea
in the East I became more interested
about this grain that was deemed worth
taking to the afterlife by early
Egyptians as I continued my research I
found out that fonio was actually
wherever it was cultivated there was
always some myths or some superstition
connected to it the Dogon another great
culture in Mali called the PO or the
seed of the universe in that ancient
cultures mythology the entire universe
sprouted from a seed of fonio aside from
its purported mystical properties phono
is a miracle grains in many aspects it
is nutritious particularly rich in
methionine and cysteine - amino acids
that are deficient in most other major
grains barley rice or wheat to name a
few in addition for new cultivation is
great for the environment
it tolerates poor soil and needs very
little water thriving were
thing else will grow as a chef what
